title: Better Double-Check Your Deposit -- A $32 Million Lesson at Citizens Bank
text:
Better Double-Check Your Deposit -- A $32 Million Lesson at Citizens Bank Written by: Valerie Young 08/13/15 - 1:55 PM EDT Tickers in this article: CFS 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- So you go to the bank, fill out your deposit slip, slide your money into the ATM or pass it to the bank teller, and you're done. Ready to go to the movies, pay your Visa bill or leave for vacation. 
You might want to double-check your account balance first, though, and make sure your bank credited your whole deposit. Citizens Bank just agreed to pay almost $32 million to settle regulators' claims that it didn't meet that basic expectation for some customers for about six years. The case is the first involving handling of deposits for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, an agency created by the Dodd-Frank Act in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. 
A subsidiary of Citizens Financial Group , which recently had the largest initial public offering for a commercial bank in U.S. history, Citizens Bank told customers that it had procedures for verifying deposit amounts and ensuring checks and cash jibed with deposit slips, but from 2008 through 2012, it ignored discrepancies of $50 or less, according to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. In 2013, it cut the threshold to $25. More Headlines Here's Why Millennials Are Going to Flood the Stock Market 
"One could argue that it all came out in the wash," bureau director Richard Cordray said in a statement. "Some consumers benefited by this policy and some were harmed by it. But for those customers who were harmed, the bank kept the difference, and over the years shorted consumers millions of dollars. We believe this practice was unfair and deceptive." 
The bureau, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. , and the Officer of the Comptroller of the Currency together assessed penalties against Providence, Rhode Island-based Citizens Bank of $20.5 million and ordered it to refund $11 million to customers. 
"When a depository institution violates the basic tenet of what it means to offer a deposit account -- that is, to receive and keep safe the customer's funds -- it imbues a deep sense of mistrust," Cordray said. "Fifty dollars may seem like a small amount to a bank with assets worth billions of dollars, but it is real money to regular people." 
Reasons for the deposit discrepancies included bank scanners misreading checks and customers providing inaccurate deposit slips, the bureau said. 
"Like many other peer banks, Citizens employed certain practices to ensure the next-day crediting of deposits in situations when deposit slips contained mathematical errors," the company said in a statement on its website. "However, these past practices and disclosures, principally prior to early 2011, could have been better." 
The bank implemented a new teller system in the last three months of 2013 that addresses the issue by automating the reconciliation process, which the bureau called "a significant technology investment." Citizens, which held $100.6 million in total deposits as of the end of June, said it has "adequate reserves" to cover the settlement. 1
